#MyKwentongCHEDUniFAST Digital Content Creation Webinar Series (November 21, 2021)

"Mayroon bang manonood sa akin? Mayroon bang makikinig sa mga sasabihin ko?"
Beauty queen and social media personality Nicole Cordoves shared that even if it might take time to build an audience, content creators should not be discouraged in creating new content. She emphasized that new content creators should put more value on the engagement they get because this is the first step to building a community.

Social media influencer Mark " Macoy Dubs" Averilla highlighted the importance of 'language' in creating engaging content. For a content to be successful in terms of engagement, the audience must first understand the message you want to convey.

"Be curious."
Film editor and teacher Ilsa Malsi advises young creators to not be afraid of trying things out with editing softwares as practice. She also pointed out that practicing early and watching a lot of videos also helps in building essential skills an editor should have.

"Magsimula na agad kayo with what you have."
Award-winning filmmaker Mark Meily ended the session on"Equipment Essentials for Vlogging" with an advice to young creators to start creating and working on their content with the current resources that they have as there is no gain in waiting for the perfect moment to come.

**REGION 6- WESTERN VISAYAS November 15-19, 2021**

LANDBANK Mastercard Prepaid Card (LMPC) Application at https://www.unifast.gov.ph/tes.lbp.app/

To facilitate the smooth process of TES Card applications and to prevent network congestion due to numerous TES grantees trying to access the portal, we will regularly post a Regional Schedule indicating when and what higher education institutions may be able to access the site on certain dates.

To know more about the #LANDBANKTESCard and how to apply, visit our website https://unifast.gov.ph/video.php or watch it on our YouTube channel UniFAST Official https://youtu.be/H5Fs_9gRg7c / https://youtu.be/tDo2AdkAQ20

Please read our important reminders on the LMPC Application:
1. The 2x2 photo, front ID and back ID images for uploading must only be in JPG/JPEG format under 2MB file size or it will cause an error on PDF generation.
2. Special characters like dash (-) and dot (.) are not allowed. Ñ/ñ in names should be typed as N/n. Double check the pre-filled names for any correction.
3. Extension names should be in the First Name field (Example: Juan Jr.)
4. Leave the field blank if there is no Middle Name.
5. Type "N/A" if there is no Tax Identification Number (TIN).
6. A ZIP code is automatically generated based on the selected province and city, except for Metro Manila that you have to input manually. Double check if the generated ZIP code is correct.
7. For mobile numbers, input the last 10 digits only. (Example: 9187481035)
8. An email address with a dash is not acceptable. Use another valid email address.
9. Click Save then Finalize to generate the application form in PDF format. By clicking the Finalize button, editing is no longer allowed.
10. The HEI focals must make sure that the log-in credential used by the grantee matches the TES Award Number assigned to the grantee, and review the"Finalized" application for submission but may"Unfinalized" it for editing when a wrong input is found.
11. View the form by clicking the word "Here" in the upper part of the page.
12. Grantees will be informed through the portal if their application is being processed by UniFAST and LANDBANK, approved, rejected or if the LMPC is ready to be claimed. For a rejected application, a Remark found by LANDBANK appears in the upper part of the page and the fields in the portal are enabled again for editing.
13. For LMPC applications with"Exported" status but needing a correction, the TES grantee or HEI should send a signed letter to email address unifast_teslmpc@ched.gov.ph requesting to change any information provided. Please address it to the UniFAST OIC Executive Director, Atty. Ryan L. Estevez, and indicate the TES Award Number, Full Name and details to be corrected. The UniFAST ICT Unit will update its records and forward the request to LANDBANK for their action.
14. For grantees having problems logging in on the LANDBANK Mastercard Integrated Cardholder's Portal, directly contact LBP's customer service numbers below:
NCR: (+632) 8 405 7000
Outside NCR: 1 800 10 405 7000

NEWS | Kapihan sa Bukid with CHED Chairman De Vera and CLSU Officials

As part of the launching of the eFARM Academy Program, an event dubbed as Kapihan sa Bukid is conducted today, February 11 at the Cabisuculan Mushroom Center, Brgy. Cabisuculan, Science City of Muñoz, Nueva Ecija graced by CHED Chairperson J. Prospero E. de Vera III, Atty. Lily Freida M. Milla, and CLSU officials led by President Edgar A. Orden.

This event seeks to intensify the partnership between CLSU, SCM LGU, and the Cabisuculan Mushroom Growers Association as one of the beneficiaries of the eFARM GROW.

"Kami po sa CLSU ay patuloy na magbabahagi ng mga teknolohiyang aming nadedebelop. Isa na nga dito ay sa pamamagitan ng Technology Village Program, at ngayon naman ay itong eFARM GROW sa ilalim ng eFARM Academy," said President Orden in his opening remarks.

Dr. Jerry A. Rigos, City Agriculturist and representative of SCM Mayor Nestor L. Alvarez, reinforced their support to any endeavours of CLSU that will strengthen and empower the farmers.

CHED Chairperson De Vera, in his message, emphasized the role of the University in its neighbouring communities.

"Mahalaga ang ginagampanan ng mga pamantasan tulad ng CLSU upang mabago at mapabuti ang buhay ng mga tao at komunidad na nasasakupan nito," he said.

In addition, he stressed that universities should prioritize on doing extension and not just research because after all, universities were established to help the nearby communities grow.

During the event, mushroom growers and association members get to ask queries with regards to their involvement in the project.

Others who joined the event were Cabisuculan Barangay Captain Benjamin Kara, Councilor Jerry Fulgencio, Association President Alexander Antonio Mapalo and their officers, and the eFARM Academy Program Team.

𝐓𝐀𝐔 𝐜𝐨𝐦𝐦𝐮𝐧𝐢𝐭𝐲 𝐫𝐞𝐯𝐢𝐬𝐢𝐭𝐬 𝐢𝐧𝐭𝐞𝐫𝐧𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧𝐚𝐥 𝐫𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐧𝐠𝐬, 𝐜𝐞𝐥𝐞𝐛𝐫𝐚𝐭𝐞𝐬 𝐇𝐢𝐠𝐡𝐞𝐫 𝐄𝐝𝐮𝐜𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧 𝐃𝐚𝐲

To assess the 2021 and 2022 performance of Tarlac Agricultural University (TAU) in the Times Higher Education (THE) IMPACT Rankings and take part in 2nd National Higher Education Day and 28th Founding Anniversary of the the Commission on Higher Education (CHED), university officials and members of clusters working on the 17 Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) convened at TAU Farmers' Training Center on 18 May.

In his message, TAU President Dr. Max P. Guillermo expressed his gratitude to all TAU stakeholders who"made valuable contributions" to improving the points earned by the university."I know many did not believe that we could do it. But with cooperation nothing is impossible," Dr. Guillermo commented. Though TAU retained its 601-800 overall rank, it recorded a double-digit increase in its gross mark this year. Dr. Guillermo also thanked CHED for its support to the initiatives of TAU.

SDG leads and their respective members evaluated their group's comparative performance and planned for interventions to improve TAU's data points for the 2023 rankings."Creating programs for employees to effect an environment that will promote decent work is one of the primary goals of the TAU as we recognize that this will become our significant contribution in bettering the lives of TAU employees and their families and helping in the country's economic recovery," Ms. Yolanda F. Juan, Chief Administrative Officer for Administration and focal person for SDG 8: Decent Work and Economic Growth, remarked.

The activity highlighted Dr. Christine N. Ferrer's reports on TAU's global and country rankings and the research component per SDG."We need to strengthen our research programs and make our data more transparent and accessible," Dr. Ferrer noted. The Director of the External Linkages and International Affairs (ELIA) also discussed the SDG alignment with QS ESG Metrics and along with Dr. Sheila R. Lingaya, ELIA Assistant Director, and Mr. Julius C. Consul, ELIA technical staff on Rankings, reviewed the data collection plan and identified the responsible office/unit for every SDG. In addition, Mr. Jerome L. Duque, ELIA technical staff, relayed the information presented in THE Masterclass he attended especially on changes and trends in the 2022 edition.

Meanwhile, TAU's top 3 SDGs were SDG 2: No Hunger, SDG 4: Quality Education, and SDG 5: Gender Equality. Topping the nation in SDG 4, members of TAU's academic council vowed to enhance its curricular and instructional strategies to maintain or even surpass its record in next year's THE standing. Dr. Ma. Theresa B. Nardo, Dean of the College of Arts and Sciences (CAS), addressed the long-standing concerns on TAU's role in advancing lifelong learning."The meaningful activities we give students will be their reference to build a sustainable future for themselves and for their communities," Dr. Nardo explained. As a member of multiple SDG groupings, Dr. Nardo also expounded on raising the living standards of families to attain maximum human development.

Last year, TAU was the only Filipino public university that made it to the list. In 2022, there are 15 Philippine higher education institutions ranked and TAU tied in third place with Central Luzon State University, MapÃƒÆ’Ã‚Âºa University, and University of Sto. Tomas.

24th of January 2023 is 5th International Day of Education!
UniFAST joins in celebrating the International Day of Education, as proclaimed by the United Nations General Assembly in 2018, to highlight the role of education in peace and development. The theme for this year's celebration is “to invest in people, prioritize education”.
In the adoption of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development in September 2015, the international community recognized that education is essential for the success of all its 17 goals. Sustainable Development Goal 4 aims to “ensure inclusive and equitable quality education and promote lifelong learning opportunities for all” by 2030.

TES Update #45 (TDP)

Gikapoy naba kag "Sana All", "Sana Owel", "Sana onnn"? Ayaw kabalaka, TDP-TES Payment ani-a na mga Higala! 🤩

To date, CHED Regional Office X handled the release of P11 million worth of funds to 35 private higher education institutions in Northern Mindanao for the 1st Semester of Academic Year 2020-2021.

Each of the 1,469 continuing grantees may now enjoy their TDP benefits equivalent to P7,500.00 as soon as they claim it by contacting their school's scholarship focal person.

Statement on Senator Risa Hontiveros’ claim on the P7 billion “questionable releases” under CHED
11 August 2022
We take seriously the allegations raised by Senator Risa Hontiveros that CHED-UniFAST has nearly P7-Billion "questionable releases" for the implementation of its programs.
The alleged “questionable releases” have been answered squarely by CHED-UNIFAST in its reply to the COA while observations (e.g. inefficient billing) requiring action from CHED-UniFAST have been corrected as these allegations stem from COA observations 3-4 years ago (AY 2018-2019 and AY 2019-2020).
CHED has always been fully transparent and accountable in its implementation of RA 10931 or the UAQTE. The beneficiaries of UAQTE are the beneficiaries mandated by the law. No UAQTE funds have been released to students who are not beneficiaries under the law.
Nevertheless, CHED is ready to meet with Senator Hontiveros to clarify her concerns. I will hold a press conference next week to explain the side of CHED and UniFAST.
(SIGNED) 
J. PROSPERO E. DE VERA III, DPA
Chairman
Commission on Higher Education

𝗦𝘁𝗮𝘁𝗲𝗺𝗲𝗻𝘁 𝗼𝗻 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗦𝗵𝗼𝗼𝘁𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗜𝗻𝗰𝗶𝗱𝗲𝗻𝘁 𝗶𝗻 𝗔𝘁𝗲𝗻𝗲𝗼 𝗱𝗲 𝗠𝗮𝗻𝗶𝗹𝗮 𝗨𝗻𝗶𝘃𝗲𝗿𝘀𝗶𝘁𝘆

24 July 2022

The Commission on Higher Education (CHED) is deeply saddened by the horrific school shooting that occurred today at Ateneo de Manila University in Quezon City.

In addition to the tragic loss of lives, such events lead to post-traumatic distress among victims and to those who have witnessed these.

I personally know Former Lamitan City Mayor Rosita Furigay, who is among the three victims, and Mayor Oric Furigay and they have received me with open arms during my visits to Lamitan City.

We would therefore like to extend our condolences to the families of the victims of this act of violence and to the Ateneo Community as a whole.

CHED, and the entire higher education community, condemn this act of violence committed inside a higher education institution (HEI). We entrust our law enforcement authorities to bring to justice those responsible for this.

This incident also highlights the importance of keeping our campuses safe and secure as places of learning, inclusivity and peace.

(SIGNED)
J. PROSPERO E. DE VERA III, DPA
Chairman
Commission on Higher Education

Hi everyone, for concerns regarding your status please do check with your TES focal first so they can look up your names in the portal. If your status is "exported" or "approved" you just need to wait for the email from landbank. If it's "finalized" your focal will take care of submitting your application for review. If it's "not finalized" you should finalize your application.


If you have concerns regarding opening the portal, please post here and include screenshots so we can see the issue.

he TES Localized Congress 2022 ended with a bang! 💥
Let's take a look back at the spectacular event and how it showcased the talents and skills of PSUans!
The morning program was held at the PSU Amphitheater, presided by our Masters of Ceremony, Ms. Glyza Glynn Almeniana and Mr. Jethro Sandrino. We are then welcomed by Dr. Elucila M. Sespeñe, the Vice President for Academic Affairs. This is followed by an inspirational message from the University President, Dr. Ramon M. Docto. We have been also graced with a message by our esteemed guest, Atty. Joselito C. Alisuag, PhD, CSEE, the CHED-MIMAROPA Regional Director.
PSU Sining Palawan Dance Troupe then performed an intermission number before the seminar proper. The first topic is by Mr. Gregorio S. Naldo, RPm, RPsy, entitled Understanding the Self, followed by Leadership and Camaraderie, by Ms. Vina Karina Baaco.
On the afternoon program at the PSU Gymnasium, we have Ms. Ysabelle Nicole Grande and Mr. Henry Lorenz Parreñas as our Masters of Ceremony. Ms. Regine Dianolo, a 4th year BS Social Work student, blessed us with an invocation, followed by PSU Singers for the National Anthem. As the contest proper kicked off, we witnessed the performance of three Contemporary Dance groups, with the CCJE Dance Club (Mary Angel T. Cayabyab & Jhon Glen De Castro) bagging the Grand Winner prize. 1st place was awarded to CBA 2 (Marlon A. Demolar & Eunice Gane C. San Juan), and 2nd place to CBA 1 (Macreo L. Gallego & Florel B. Borja). Ms. Ailene Z. Bautista, a 4th year BS Criminology student, then showcased her talent for an intermission number before the second half of the program.
We then jammed with the Battle of the Bands contestants for the second part of the program, where Royale won as the Grand Winner, followed by CCJE Band for the 1st place. WAKABS won the 2nd place, and WAKOBS for the 3rd place. We have also been joined by The Crudes and the CHTM Band. Dr. Grace N. Abrina delivered the closing remarks as the event comes to an end.
***
This event would not be successful if not for the team behind that made it possible.
Team OSAS, spearheaded by Ms. Kristy Talatagod, with Mr. Jethro Sandrino, and Mr. Ric Henry Pagmanoja. Committee leads; Ms. Glyza Almeniana, Ms. Vina Karina Baaco, Ms. Katrina Martinez, Ms. Veyrainchiel Nacasi, and Ms. Evangeline Dela Cruz. Along with Dr. Grace Abrina, Prof. Lucia Fresnillo, Mr. Mark Mendoza, Ms. Ana Marquez, and Ms. Elma Eleazar.
Special thanks to TATSULOK, Psu Pio, Pioneer Publication, Mr. Elijah Daniel Geanga of PSU Medua Hub and John Paul Roman of SEPO for covering the entire event, as well as the teasers of the contestants. Also to Mr. Daryll Homecillo as the lead graphic designer for the visuals, together with Mr. Mattheo Yves Tamayor.
Thank you to the students that showcased their talents during the intermission segments of the program: PSU Sining Palawan Dance Troupe, Ms. Ailene Z. Bautista of BS Criminology, Mr. Gerrict E. Lapida and Mr. June Ocampo of BS Architecture, SIGNUS Band, and Ms. Regine Dianolo of BS Social Work.
Huge thanks to the CSG Governors for their utmost support and cooperation: Mary Hope Hayagan of CBA, Dorothy Grace Matillano of CNHS, Ailene Bautista of CCJE, Kimberly Romero of CEAT, Jessica Evardo of CHMT, Jobelle Cervantes of CS, Claude Betita of CAH, and John Ellie Moncatar of CTE.
And you, for being among the audience of the event! Thank you for your participation!

The Commission on Higher Education(CHED) and Unified Student Financial System for Tertiary Education (UniFAST), in partnership with the Film Development Council of the Philippines (FDCP) Film School, are launching the #MyKwentongCHEDUniFAST series of webinars for students who aspire to become digital content creators.

Taking the lead as mentors are filmmakers Ilsa Malsi, Tara Illenberger, and Mark Meily to be joined by vloggers/social media influencers Mark 'Macoy Dubs' Averilla, Nicole Cordoves, and Joyce Pring.

#MyKwentongCHEDUniFAST is an educational program that aims to teach students how to create digital media content and to give them a platform to share and highlight their experiences and stories on being recipients of UniFAST. Participants who will be able to complete the whole course may claim a certificate signed by CHED, UniFAST, and FDCP.

The #MyKwentongCHEDUniFAST webinars will be spread throughout the months of November and December of this year.

This project is exclusive to student beneficiaries of the Free Higher Education (FHE) and Tertiary Education Subsidy/Tulong Dunong Program (TES-TDP) under RA 10931 or the Universal Access to Quality Tertiary Education Act. Number of participants or slots are allocated per higher education institution.

Pandemya: Ang Paghamon Sa Katatagan

Ang pagguho nang pag-asang mabuhay dahil sa pagkatakot. Pagkatakot sa maaring mangyari. Sa kadahilanang, walang lunas sa sakit na dumapo. Ang pagkabigla't pagkalugmok sa resultang umahon mula sa ilog nang kalungkuta't pagkadismayado. Ang paghina ng pundasyon at pagtumba nang pader dahil sa lindol ng dalamhati't pasakit.

Mula sa isang karamdamang walang lunas umusbong ang pag-asa dahil sa tiwala sa nakakaalam. Ang patnubay at gabay nang Diyos sa akin ng mga panahong iyon. Ang pagmamahal na sumalubong at humalili sa akin ng oras na iyon. Naging mitsa sa pag-usbong nang tapang sa'king puso. Ang pagkabuhay nang apoy sa aking dibdib. Ang apoy na sumunog sa kawalang pag-asa dahil sa isang sakit.

Ang pag-ulan nang pagmamahal mula sa mga taong nagmamahal. Ang pagbigay nang biyaya na galing sa Diyos at pinagkaloob niya gamit ang mga taong nasa officeina Nang Kaalaman.
Ang pagkaloob Tertiary Education Subsidy ang naging unang hakbang sa pagbangon mula kalugmukan. Ang naging dahilan sa pag-asang makaahon sa hagupit nang kahirapan.

Maraming Salamat!

IN May, Commission on Higher Education (CHEd) Chairman Prospero de Vera 3rd sparked a furor when he declared that there would be "no going back to the traditional full-packed face-to-face classrooms."
With people desperate for a return to normalcy and an end to the issues that plagued schooling because of the pandemic, the statement naturally drew flak. De Vera explained, however, that the flexible learning track pushed by the CHEd would give schools more options to address the needs of students.
"School administrators are aware that not all can go back to face-to-face [classes] because there are other good options available by combining online and face-to-face. If we say that the only mode is face-to-face and another pandemic hits, we go back to March 2020 and ask everyone to go home again," he said."

Click the link to read more: https://www.manilatimes.net/2021/09/21/news/national/no-end-to-transformation-of-education/1815492?fbclid=IwAR2iUojli_4jyyBDj4XmTEk8gbZkx32Sxkr93912uqHqmV_-Qyrxqc3Z8R8

NEWS FEATURE: Cortez of OCD-CAR Urges HEIs to Strengthen DCG in Second Episode of SEED Project 
The Commission on Higher Education - Cordillera Administrative Region (CHED-CAR) Unified Student Financial Assistance System for Tertiary Education (UniFAST) Unit successfully conducted the second episode of its learning and development project dubbed as the SEED (Skill Enhancement and Employee Development) Project on Tuesday, July 19, 2022, via Zoom platform. The second among the monthly series is in celebration of the annual National Disaster Resilience Month (NDRM) with the theme "Sambayanang Pilipino, Nagkakaisa Tungo sa Katatagan at Maunlad na Kinabukasan.”
Mr. Frankie Cortez, Chief for Operations of the Office of the Civil Defense - Cordillera Administrative Region, served as the resource speaker for the said episode and lectured on promoting disaster resilience in the workplace and in the community. He highlighted to the participants the importance of having a strong and firm Disaster Control Group (DCG) in every agency as the main support of the organization when a disaster arises. The DCG is responsible for ensuring the safety of the members of the organization during an emergency or disaster. 
A total of forty-one (41) participants attended the webinar which includes the employees of the Regional Office and UniFAST Focal Persons of various higher education institutions in the Region. 
The SEED Project is an initiative of the CHED-CAR UniFAST Unit under the leadership of Dr. Demetrio P. Anduyan Jr, Director IV, that aims to promote excellence in client service through the provision of learning and development programs for its employees and UniFAST Focal Persons from its partner HEIs in the Region.

CHED's entry to the Bicol Regional Development Council Parol Making Contest.

Pls click the photo, it will lead you to the NEDA website, pls click heart on CHED's entry. Salamat po

The"parol" signifies the mission and vision of the Commission on Higher Education, which envisions a Philippine higher education system that is locally responsive and globally competitive and serves as a force for lifelong learning, innovation, and social and cultural transformation. As embodied in our parol, the CHED logo is located at the center of the parol with rays of the rising sun extending to the six corners of the star, which represents CHED ROV reaching out to the six provinces of the Bicol region, which comprises its different stakeholders, by giving higher education the much-needed attention and appropriate reforms. Also, the dominant colors in our parol, like red, yellow, white, and blue, correspond to the colors of the Philippine flag, as CHED was created to be the primary advocate and pillar of nation-building.

ALL STUDENTS WHO ARE GRANTEES OF THE TERTIARY EDUCATION SUBSIDY (TES) from CHED must report to the Registrar's Office for more requirements needed. Please read the MEMO and submit the requirements before Oct 29. Otherwise, you will not receive any subsidy. For strict compliance.

Our commencement speaker Associate Justice Bautista Corpin Jr. said that, "what you dream is what you become". This reminds me of myself four years ago as I planned to go to college at Eastern Visayas State University. I dreamed of myself graduating at the said university with the course Bachelor of Science in Information Technology. And that dream turns into reality. I am now the product of my dream. A person who surpassed all the circumstances along the long and tough journey of college years.

Four years ago I find myself a bit confused on what course to take because my parents wanted me to pursue education-related courses. Everyone is expecting that I'll choose education because I took up HUMSS in Senior High School and I am that capable to be a future educator (I claim it). But I am eager to take risks and explore new things so I ended up challenging myself taking BSIT.

Being an IT student requires full attention because once you lose a bit of it is difficult to catch up. Back when I was a first year student, we were bombarded with lots of activities; school works in all subjects to be submitted on the next day at the same time, exam-like quizzes every other day, surprised practical and hands-on exams in major and minor subjects every week, and movie making every end of semester. Additionally, there were these subjects scheduled at night, 6-8 pm to be specific. Because of that, I left home, and became independent by staying in a boarding house. I only went home every weekend or after 2 to 3 weeks depending on how busy I am. My parents were selling bibingka everyday for me to have 500-700 pesos weekly allowance. I am sometimes in tears while holding my allowance because I know that the money in my hands came from my parents' hardships and sacrifices. And I have 5 more siblings going to school. Because of that, I practiced myself to be frugal all the time. But there were times I skipped meals because my allowance was shortened due to some school expenses. I went to school sometimes with an empty stomach and I even collapsed during my practical in P.E. because of hunger. However, school expenses are still there with a growing amount. So I decided to accept paper works from other students in college, senior high, and junior high. I wrote their essays, reflection papers, critique papers, research papers and reports, business plans, and other paper works I can do. The payment I get from them were used to pay other school expenses and if there were excess I used it to buy clothes and shoes.

I am blessed as I was chosen to be one of the lucky grantees of Tertiary Education Subsidy (TES) before the academic year ends. The subsidy given to me is a big help to my studies and expenses. I got the chance to buy my own cellphone because my cellphone back then was an old model, second hand, Samsung given by my sister. I also paid my boarding house monthly fee in 5 months advance. And I gave the rest of my allowance to my parents for our family's expenses.

The routine in first year is exactly the same during second year, however the activities became more difficult and that few of my classmates starting to shift courses. Seeing them pursuing new courses is a discouragement to me in continuing IT. But I remember my dream on the very beginning, to graduate with my chosen course, and that dream weighed heavier than the discouragements that surround me.

But the strongest enemy came-\-\the pandemic. I was stucked in home with greater challenges await. In a blink of an eye, the traditional face to face classes turns into virtual classes. The sudden shift of learning modality is a disadvantage to me to maintain my standing in class. It is because my home is in a remote barangay of Pastrana with a poor to no internet connection at all. So to attend my online classes, I stayed at our roof for plenty of hours and the people passing by who saw my setup laughed at me. But what else can I do? That is the only way to attend online class. And because of the setup, I got lower grades and I even got an INC from one of my major subjects then my GWA started to decrease. I got stressed, experienced deep sadness, lose weight, and diagnosed with ulcer. I got sick almost every month suffering from intense stomach pain. Thanks to God, after taking some medications I overcome it.

I am lucky, though, when everything is slowly going back to normal. My parents allowed me to attend my online classes at Nanay Hilda's residence at Pastrana proper. So I travelled everyday from home to Pastrana proper and I considered it as an opportunity to comply with all of my lacking activities as well as my INC. I continued doing my sideline while I discovered to earn online through answering surveys from LifePoints and Tangere, and participating in ViewPoints. I also joined online gameshows like Cash Cash Pinas, DongBam Negoshow, PinaSadya PinaSwerte, PinasForward and many more. I also experienced getting scammed by some messenger bots. Hahaha. Then I started collecting e-certificates from webinars and trainings of PinasForward and DICT.

FOUR years have passed and those experiences are fresh in my mind. The achievements and failures altogether helped me to grow and become the person I am today. The biggest achievement I have right now is because of the people behind my college journey. So I will take this opportunity to thank them all.

To God, above all, for always hearing my prayers. For being my silent bestfriend whom I tell my pain and burden. Thank you so much for the blessings you've given to me!😇

To my family, who supported me financially, who believed and trusted me all throughout my journey. I promise to reciprocate your hardships and sacrifices thrice or more. Thank you so much, ma, pa, ate airah, ate kathlene, and kuya clynton!🤗

To Nanay Hilda Doria, and Apuya family, my second family, who also witnessed my hardships, thank you so much for allowing me to be your VIP visitor everyday! Your kindness is incomparable. Thank you so much!🤗😇

To CHED Unifast, thank you for the financial support through Tertiary Education Subsidy! I am lucky to be one of your grantees!😇

To DOLE and Municipality of Pastrana, thank you also for having me as a SPES (Special Program for Employment of Students) baby. The said program is helpful for a student who suffers financially. I am also lucky to be one of it!😇

To my former teachers in JVMHS and my grade 6 adviser, Sir Noel Baguilod, thank you so much for the knowledge I've gained from all of you! Thank you also for the advices and encouragements!😇

To my instructors in EVSU, sir Daylo, sir Sta. Singh, ma'am Lyra, ma'am Ritch (our thesis adviser), and many more, thank you so much for enhancing my skills. Your efforts are indeed priceless! 😇

To my friends, Bob Ongs, Laagers, my thesis group Legendary Pokemons, my classmates, di ko na uusa usahon kay damo kamo, thank you so much for being part of my college journey! Thank you for the happy memories we shared together! Pangarigo soon! Kay diri man kamo hingarigo!😂 See you when I see you!😆 

To my special bestfriend/jowa/enemy/partner in crime/study buddy, Mano Jay, thank you for being my number one supporter and adviser, my kabulig ha akon assignments, my taga-edit ng videos, my taga-palit hin snacks, and many more roles in my life! Thank you so much for the support, care, and love. This is for you!😇🤗 I love you!

THANK YOU SO MUCH, EVERYONE! THIS ACHIEVEMENT IS FOR Y'ALL!!🤗

Mga ka-Marites, bilnga gud it mga wrong grahams ngan icomment nala ha ubos!😆 😂 Sorry po kay diri ak English major!😆 

Kung si Associate Justice Bautista Corpin Jr. Ay nagsabi ng "what you dream is what you become". I, Yvonn Kyla V. Magallon, a degree holder and a Latin Honor pa, nagsasabi ng, "what you dream is what you become, may pasobra pa!".😆  I am now signing off as a student and dakilang sideliner and I welcome my new role as an "unemployed pressured fresh graduate"!

YVONN KYLA VILLASAN MAGALLON
COLLEGE OF ENGINEERING
BACHELOR OF SCIENCE IN INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY
CUM LAUDE

CHED and UniFAST join in the celebration of ASEAN's 54th founding anniversary: We care, We prepare, We prosper

The Association of Southeast Asian Nations, or ASEAN, was established on 8 August 1967 in Bangkok, Thailand, with the signing of the ASEAN Declaration (Bangkok Declaration) by the Founding Fathers of ASEAN, namely Indonesia, Malaysia, Philippines, Singapore and Thailand. Brunei Darussalam then joined on 7 January 1984, Viet Nam on 28 July 1995, Lao PDR and Myanmar on 23 July 1997, and Cambodia on 30 April 1999, making up what is today the ten-member states of ASEAN.

ASEAN supports global and regional commitments in education by promoting lifelong learning underpinned by the principles of equity, inclusion and quality. One of the highlights of ASEAN's work in education includes supports for students and learners transition to the workforce through internship opportunities, higher education scholarships and responsive skills development.

TES UPDATE #13
Hala Bira, Western Visayas! Ang inyo TES ari na! 🥳
Through the collaborative efforts of UniFAST and CHED Regional Office 6, sixty-four (64) state universities and colleges (SUCs) and local universities and colleges (LUCs) received TES grants to cover 12,168 continuing grantees in Western Visayas.
Aside from free tuition benefits in these public universities and colleges, grantees will receive P20,000 1st Semester subsidy to support education expenses especially during this time of pandemic.
Moreover, 20 continuing grantees from Bago Community College are already processed for payment while the remaining 2,371 from University of Antique (Main, Hamtic and Tario Lim Antique School of Fisheries Campus) will immediately receive their well-deserved subsidy once funds are released from the DBM. 
To all grantees, please give your schools ample time to prepare for the release grants so just keep in touch with the respective TES Focal persons once they settle the schedule of TES distribution.

UNIFAST RECORDS 99% IN ITS FINANCIAL PERFORMANCE FOR TWO (2) YEARS IN A ROW!
-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\
Press Release
July 18, 2022

DBM lauds CHED's physical, financial and income performance

Commission on Higher Education (CHED) not only met but exceeded its physical targets for 2021, with some indicators recording notably high accomplishment rates for the period of January to December 2021.

This is the evaluation of the Department of Budget and Management (DBM) after completing the review of CHED's performance, particularly agency utilization of government funds vis-a-vis plans/targets.

"The accomplishments of CHED proved its commitment of delivering dynamic tertiary education services to the public," DBM Undersecretary Tina Rose Marie L. Canda stated in its written review sent to CHED recently.

In terms of financial performance, CHED achieved 92% (obligation vs. allotment) in FY 2021, which is higher than its performance in FY 2020 of 82%. The budget utilization of CHED prior to the Duterte administration was 78%.

CHED has two major programs, namely the Higher Education Regulation Program (HERP) and Higher Education Development Program (HEDP) for which the budget allocated in the FY 2021 General Appropriations Act is P427.853 million and P49.962 billion, respectively.

The HERP covers the regular activities of CHED such as monitoring and evaluation of higher education programs, formulation of policies for higher education institutions, and development of standards for higher education.

The bulk of HEDP funds go to various scholarship programs including the Universal Access to Quality Tertiary Education (UAQTE) with a budget of Php 44.288 billion.

CHED's financial performance (obligation vs. allotment) showed very high obligation rates for UAQTE (99%), StuFAPS (90%), and Subsidy for Tuition Fees of Medical Students in SUCs (68%).

CHED has shifted to cash based budgeting for most of its programs starting 2020. The practice of synchronizing the budget by fiscal year, and not by academic year, and the direct release of funds to CHED ROs for the implementation of the Tertiary Education Subsidy (TES) and Tulong Dunong Program (TDP), proved to be effective in improving the obligation rate of CHED, according to the DBM Report.

CHED's revenue performance recorded a notable accomplishment rate of 129%. This was due to the increase in the collection of permit, application and inspection fees because of the increased volume of application for Certificate of Program Compliance (COPC) which is required for all public universities to ensure quality assurance of their degree programs.

"DBM conducts an annual monitoring and review of an agency's performance, particularly its utilization of government funds vis-ÃƒÆ’Ã‚Â -vis their plans and targets. CHED also got a positive review of its 2020 budget performance last year. With this year's results of the DBM's review to serve as a guide, we will now focus on improving our disbursement rate to ensure the timely delivery of its programs," De Vera said.

(SIGNED)
J. PROSPERO E. DE VERA III, DPA
Chairman
Commission on Higher Education
UniFAST Governing Board

CHED and UniFAST join in the celebration of the Civil Service Month as stated in Presidential Proclamation No. 1050, series of 1997. 
The Civil Service Commission (CSC) spearheads the 121st Anniversary of the Philippine Civil Service in observance of the establishment of the Philippine Civil Service by virtue of Public Law No. 5 (An Act for the Establishment and Maintenance of an Efficient and Honest Civil Service in the Philippine Islands) on 19 September 1900.
The CSC also introduces a 10-year overarching theme, 𝙏𝙧𝙖𝙣𝙨𝙛𝙤𝙧𝙢𝙞𝙣𝙜 𝙋𝙪𝙗𝙡𝙞𝙘 𝙎𝙚𝙧𝙫𝙞𝙘𝙚 𝙞𝙣 𝙩𝙝𝙚 𝙉𝙚𝙭𝙩 𝘿𝙚𝙘𝙖𝙙𝙚: 𝙃𝙤𝙣𝙞𝙣𝙜 𝘼𝙜𝙞𝙡𝙚 𝙖𝙣𝙙 𝙁𝙪𝙩𝙪𝙧𝙚-𝙍𝙚𝙖𝙙𝙮 𝙎𝙚𝙧𝙫𝙖𝙣𝙩-𝙃𝙚𝙧𝙤𝙚𝙨, reflecting the path the civil service has to take to build on the gains of last year’s modernization efforts in the wake of the COVID-19 pandemic, and the role of HR in building a competent and credible workforce in the new normal.

DIVINE B. ARANAS
COLEGIO DE SAN FRANCISCO JAVIER OF RIZAL ZAMBOANGA DEL NORTE, INC.

Title of the Piece: Victory in Philippine Higher Education Amidst Crisis

Brief Description of the Piece:
The piece aims to encourage my co-scholars to continue striving in their education despite the problems that each of us is facing because the Commission on Higher Education is all willing to support us and provide us financial aid to cope our needs as students. Also, this piece intends to tell everyone that CHED has succeeded its aim to guarantee academic freedom by proving them that I, as one of CHED's scholars, was able to continue educating myself unending support, and so did my fellow scholars.

The 2022 Regional ASEAN Celebration finally culminated in the Subanen Hall of Garden Orchid Hotel on December 19, 2022. February 23-24, 2022
PADYAKarunungan 2022: “Tulong at Dunong para sa de Kalidad na Edukasyon
Leadership Training/Workshop
One of the highlights of PADYAKarunungan 2022 is the Leadership Training/Workshop attended by Marinduque HEI Student Leaders and beneficiaries of RA 10931 or Universal Access to Quality Tertiary Education Act (UAQTEA). Dr. Mark Anthony D. Latoja, Program Head-MBA and PHD College Instructor of Saint Louis College of San Fernando, La Union facilitated the workshop and shared his wisdom and brilliant insights to our participants on how to become future excellent leaders in their own field. 
Among Dr. Latoja’s discussion points are the different styles of a leader, their character, trusting and influencing people. These topics are a big help for the attendees in transforming to leadership roles in the future whether in industry or government. Dr. Latoja gained the students trust and most of the attendees joined enthusiastically in the activities and provided positive feedback regarding the conduct of the training. 
“As an intial step to become an effective leader, we should sanitize our social media accounts, because what we post is a reflection of ourselves, our thoughts, our emotions, our character”– Dr. Mark Anthony D. Latoja.

Alam mo ba?

Ang buwan ng Agosto ay idineklara ng dating Pangulong Fidel V. Ramos bilang Buwan ng Wikang Pambansa sa bisa ng Proklamasyon Bilang 1041 serye 1997 noong Hulyo 15, 1997. Ito ay bilang pagsunod sa kapanganakan ng itinuturing nating Ama ng Wikang Pambansa na si dating Pangulong Manuel L. Quezon, na isinilang noong Agosto 19, 1878.

Bilang pakikiisa sa Buwan ng Wikang Pambansa ngayong Agosto, kami ay magbabahagi ng mga kaalaman o salita sa Wikang Filipino at ito ay ipo-"post" dito sa ating grupo tuwing lunes.

Maraming Salamat at Maligayang Buwan ng Wika!

**REGION 5- BICOL REGION November 22-30, 2021**
LANDBANK Mastercard Prepaid Card (LMPC) Application at https://www.unifast.gov.ph/tes.lbp.app/

To facilitate the smooth process of TES Card applications and to prevent network congestion due to numerous TES grantees trying to access the portal, we will regularly post a Regional Schedule indicating when and what higher education institutions may be able to access the site on certain dates.

To know more about the #LANDBANKTESCard and how to apply, visit our website https://unifast.gov.ph/video.php or watch it on our YouTube channel UniFAST Official https://youtu.be/H5Fs_9gRg7c / https://youtu.be/tDo2AdkAQ20

Please read our important reminders on the LMPC Application:
1. The 2x2 photo, front ID and back ID images for uploading must only be in JPG/JPEG format under 2MB file size or it will cause an error on PDF generation.
2. Special characters like dash (-) and dot (.) are not allowed. Ñ/ñ in names should be typed as N/n. Double check the pre-filled names for any correction.
3. Extension names should be in the First Name field (Example: Juan Jr.)
4. Leave the field blank if there is no Middle Name.
5. Type "N/A" if there is no Tax Identification Number (TIN).
6. A ZIP code is automatically generated based on the selected province and city, except for Metro Manila that you have to input manually. Double check if the generated ZIP code is correct.
7. For mobile numbers, input the last 10 digits only. (Example: 9187481035)
8. An email address with a dash is not acceptable. Use another valid email address.
9. Click Save then Finalize to generate the application form in PDF format. By clicking the Finalize button, editing is no longer allowed.
10. The HEI focals must make sure that the log-in credential used by the grantee matches the TES Award Number assigned to the grantee, and review the"Finalized" application for submission but may"Unfinalized" it for editing when a wrong input is found.
11. View the form by clicking the word "Here" in the upper part of the page.
12. Grantees will be informed through the portal if their application is being processed by UniFAST and LANDBANK, approved, rejected or if the LMPC is ready to be claimed. For a rejected application, a Remark found by LANDBANK appears in the upper part of the page and the fields in the portal are enabled again for editing.
13. For LMPC applications with"Exported" status but needing a correction, the TES grantee or HEI should send a signed letter to email address unifast_teslmpc@ched.gov.ph requesting to change any information provided. Please address it to the UniFAST OIC Executive Director, Atty. Ryan L. Estevez, and indicate the TES Award Number, Full Name and details to be corrected. The UniFAST ICT Unit will update its records and forward the request to LANDBANK for their action.
14. For grantees having problems logging in on the LANDBANK Mastercard Integrated Cardholder's Portal, directly contact LBP's customer service numbers below:
NCR: (+632) 8 405 7000
Outside NCR: 1 800 10 405 7000

TES UPDATE #30
Napagalaw na ng CALABARZON TES cuties ang baso! Narito na si TES! 🙌
Tara na't magdiwang dahil 780 continuing grantees mula sa 15 state universities and colleges (SUCs) at local universities and colleges (LUCs) ng Region IV ang tatanggap ng kanilang Tertiary Education Subsidy na nagkakahalaga ng P20,000.00 para sa unang semestre ng Academic Year 2020-2021. Suma total, ang pondo na nagkakahalaga ng P15,756,000.00 ay ipinagkaloob ng UniFAST katuwang ang CHEDRO CALABARZON sa mga estudyanteng nangangailangan ng pinansyal na tulong para sa pag-aaral lalo na sa panahon ng pandemya.
Para sa mga pampublikong paaralan na hindi pa napabilang sa listahan, kasalukuyan nang pino-proseso ng CHEDRO CALABARZON ang agarang pamamahagi ng subsidy sa mga nalalabing continuing grantees. Tinitiyak namin na matatanggap ninyo ang TES sa lalong madaling panahon.  
Kung ikaw ay isa sa mga eligible grantee na tatanggap ng subsidy, mangyaring makipag-ugnayan sa inyong TES Focal Person para malaman ang schedule at proseso ng distribution.
Kinilig ka ba, TES cutie? 🥰 Dahil diyan, ipakita ang pampa-good vibes na memes at i-tag ang UniFAST sa inyong public post.

BANGON...mahigit isang taon na mula ng huli tayong bumangon at dumanas ng buhay ng nakasanayang estudyante. Mahigit isang taon, na patuloy tayong nagsisikap na umahon at bumangon sa kabila ng hirap at pagsubok na dala ng pandemya't kahirapan. Mahigit isang taon, na tayong lumalaban sa pag-abot ng ating Pangarap. Kaya naman samahan niyo kaming magbalik tanaw sa kahapong nagdaan. Sama-sama nating alalahanin ang pagsubok na atin nang nalagpasan. Inihahandog ng mga piling talentado at numero unong estudyante ng Palawan State University ang ilang sining na mula sa mga talata na isinulat sa mga pilas ng kwaderno, kapares ng malikhaing isip.

NEWS FEATURE: CHED-CAR UniFAST Kicks Off SEEDLING Project 2023 Series with a Mental Health Topic
In its eager quest to champion accessible and relevant education in the Cordillera Administrative Region, the Commission on Higher Education - Cordillera Administrative Region through its UniFAST Unit conducted the first episode of this year’s series of the SEEDLING Project or the Skills Enhancement, Engagement, and Development: A Learning Intervention to Nurture Grantees on January 30, 2023, via Zoom and Facebook Live.
The kickoff episode focused on the topic “Coping with Academic Stress” with its hope to provide student-grantees with a platform to generate mental health awareness amongst them and to develop and strengthen their coping mechanism in dealing with academic stresses to promote proactive personality for academic achievement. 
Serving as the Resource Person, Dr. Geraldine S. Orasing, Special Science Teacher III of the Philippine Science High School - CAR Campus, advised on ways in coping with academic stress and emphasized the importance of having quality self-care despite haggling tasks. 
A total of 172 attendees consisting of grantees and beneficiaries of the grants-in-aid programs under RA 10931 or the Universal Access to Quality Tertiary Education Act and other interested youth completed the webinar.
Also part of the webinar is the provision of updates on the quest for autonomy of the Region. Ms. Menzie O. Kuengan, Supervising Education Program Specialist, presented the autonomy and development updates of the Region. 
The SEEDLING Project is an initiative of the CHED-CAR UniFAST Unit under the leadership of Dr. Demetrio P. Anduyan Jr, Director IV, that aims to enhance the skills, establish engagement, and spearhead development for grantees and beneficiaries of RA 10931 in the Region through the provision of learning and development series. The next episode of the project is set to be conducted in March 2023. 
#chedCARes 
#CHEDCARUNIFAST
#SEEDLINGProject

CALLING ALL STUDENT FILMMAKERS, NOW IS THE CHANCE TO SHOWCASE YOUR FILMMAKING SKILLS! ÃƒÂ°Ã…Â¸Ã…Â½Ã‚Â¬
Have your filmmaker hats ready and get your cameras rolling! The submission of short film entries for the 'CineIskool Film Lab and Festival' is EXTENDED until November 30, 2021.
Led by the Commission on Higher Education-Unified Student Financial System for Tertiary Education (CHED-UniFAST), and in partnership with the Film Development Council of the Philippines (FDCP), 'CineIskool Film Lab and Festival' aims to showcase diverse stories which give different voices in the community the opportunity to highlight the importance of tertiary education.
All films that will be featured in the festival must be in documentary or narrative form spotlighting the real stories of the recipients of the beneficiaries of the Universal Access to Quality Tertiary Education Act program granted to students of State Universities and Colleges (SUCs) and the like.
Send your short film entries to filmlab.fdcp@gmail.com with the subject "Application for CineIskool 2021." To apply, download the application form here: bit.ly/CineIskoolApplicationForm. For more information, kindly visit: bit.ly/CineIskoolFilmLab.

HAPPY WORLD TEACHERS' DAY!
October 5, 2022

UniFAST joins in the celebration of the 28th anniversary of World Teachers' Day and National Teachers' Day! This year's theme,"The Transformation of Education Begins with Teachers", goes beyond honoring and thanking everyone who is in the teaching profession for their service and contribution to education. It calls on countries to invest in teachers and quality public education systems.

We recognize the crucial role of educators and their value in developing the minds of our Free Higher Education and Tertiary Education Subsidy (Republic Act 10931) beneficiaries nationwide.

OPEN CALL FOR ENTRIES for CINEISKOOL SHORT FILM LAB!

CHED-UniFAST, in partnership with the Film Development Council of the Philippines, opens the call for entries for CINEISKOOL!

CINEISKOOL consists of two components, a short film lab and a film festival. The short film lab program will choose 10 projects from a pool of applications that will each be given a grant worth PHP 125,000 to produce a 5-minute short film; PHP 100,000 for production costs and PHP 25,000 for safe filming protocols.

Each project will undergo online intensive film labs via Zoom, covering topics on Production Management, Story Development, Technical, Safe Filming, and Editing, mentored by award-winning filmmakers and producers in the industry.

After undergoing the intensive labs, the 10 projects will be officially recognized through a film festival.

ELIGIBILITY
The competition is open to all students who are currently enrolled and are beneficiaries of the Universal Access to Quality Tertiary Education Act or RA 10931 programs. Submissions from Luzon, Visayas and Mindanao are encouraged.

GUIDELINES
The competition is open to scriptwriter-director pairs with real stories to share with currently enrolled beneficiaries of quality tertiary education. (Applicants must present a School ID or Certification of Enrollment and Registration Card)

The proponent and owner of the story must either be the scriptwriter or director of the team.

The entries must be in documentary or narrative form. Animation and experimental films will not be accepted.

The total running time (TRT) of the completed film output must not exceed five minutes, including the opening and closing credits of the film.

The completed film output must have its premiere during the CineIskool Short Film Festival, to be held in 2022.

The rights of the completed film output will belong to the proponent. However, FDCP and CHED-UNIFAST will reserve non-commercial rights to screen entries in various events and platforms.

The team must send two of their members to all the required online film labs.

The use of original literary sources, music materials and film footage must have proper clearance from their respective copyright owners before they can be used in the final output. The Festival organizers shall not be liable for any costs related to claims of performing rights organizations.

By entering the Festival, the participants agree to abide by the Festival guidelines and rules.

In case of any violation of the guidelines and rules, the organizers and the judging committee reserves the right to disqualify the participant and their film or remove them from the program.

The organizers and the judging committee reserves the right to disqualify any participant and/or to forfeit any prize from a participant who is found to have committed plagiarism or has undertaken fraudulent practice and/or activities harmful to the Festival or the Festival submission process.

FDCP reserves the right to create, revoke and modify at any time, in any way its entry requirements, rules and regulations at its absolute discretion without prior notice. Finalists and submitted entries shall be bound by any amendments or addition to the entry requirements, rules and regulations herewith.

The decision of the selection committee is final and irrevocable. The organizers and the judging committee are not obliged to give explanations for the results.

ENTRY REQUIREMENTS

The following requirements must be submitted online in an organized google drive folder with shared viewing settings.

DULY ACCOMPLISHED APPLICATION FORM with complete details (Complete name and contact details, Working Title, Synopsis, Director/Scriptwriter Intention's Note, Concept and Financial Plan)

Application form can be downloaded via this link: bit.ly/CineIskoolForm

School ID or Certification of Enrolment and Registration Card as proof of being a beneficiary of the Universal Access to Quality Tertiary Education Act.

Online link to one (1) previously produced short film (if applicable). (Note: the online link must be set to private and the link and password must be uploaded via Vimeo or Google Drive).

Brief resume, HD profile photo, and a copy of a government-issued ID of the filmmaker.

Story concept (in PDF) and/or script if available.

AWARDS

Best Film - PHP 50,000.00
Special Jury Prize - PHP 30,000.00
Best Director - PHP 20,000.00

Send your entries to filmlab.fdcp@gmail.com with the subject "Application for CineIskool 2021" on or before October 31, 2021.

For more information, kindly visit this link: bit.ly/CineIskoolFilmLab

Good morning po ma'am/sir update ko lang po kung ibabalik nyo po pa kami sa list sa mga natanggal po sa list ng grantee. Kasi po hindi nila ilagay yung grades ko sa portal ko kasi po daw malaki po yung balance ko. So na INC po ako sa ibang subject ko bawat isang subject na na'inc ay kaylangan ko pa po mag bayad at kumuha nag form at kaylangan ko din daw po mabayaran yung balance ko para po mailagay na nila yung grades ko sa portal ko. Sana po matulungan nyo po ako na maibalik yung name ko sa list ng grantee para po makapag enrolled na din po ako. Hindi po namin kayang mabayaran yung tuition ko kaya sa TES lang po kami umaasa single parents na po si mama kaya po sana matulungan nyo po ako maibalik yung name ako sa list ng grantee para po makapag tapos ako ng pagaaral ko.
Maraming salamat po!

TES Update #55

Ayaw na rin talaga paawat ng TES sa CALABARZON! 🙌

Karagdagang 4,203 continuing TES grantees mula sa 25 state universities and colleges (SUCs) at local universities and colleges (LUCs) sa Region IV ang tatanggap na ng P20,000.00 subsidiya para sa unang semestre ng Academic Year 2020-2021.

Sa kabuuan, umabot na sa halagang P100,656,600.00 o katumbas ng 4,983 estudyante sa mga pampublikong pamantasan sa rehiyon ang nabigyan ng subsidiya ng UniFAST sa pakikipagtulungan ng CHED Regional Office CALABARZON.

Patuloy naman ang pakikipag-ugnayan ng Regional Office sa iba pang pamantasan na kasalukuyang nagpapasa ng TES billing documents upang kaagad na mabayaran ang TES sa oras na bumaba ang pondo mula sa DBM.

Excited na bang makuha ang inyong TES? Chill lang tayo, cuties! 😊½ Makipag-ugnayan muna sa TES Focal Person ng inyong paaralan para malaman kung paano at kailangan ang schedule ng distribution.

Gusto ng UniFAST lagi kayong updated kahit na holiday! 😉 Kaya patuloy na I-SHARE, LIKE at FOLLOW ang aming page para sa susunod na TES updates!

TES Update #127

Bago tayo dumako sa inaasam-asam na 2nd Sem, narito ang pinaka-latest sa 1st Semester TES ng continuing cuties! 🔥

Since CHED and UniFAST started the release of AY 2020-2021 TES grants in June 2021, more than P8 Billion worth of 1st Semester benefits were made available in 1,580 partner higher education institutions (HEIs) to reach 306,126 or 96% of continuing TES grantees across all regions. 🤩

As of the latest report, additional 4,367 continuing grantees may now access their grants in 53 public and private HEIs through the simultaneous disbursement made by the CHED Regional Offices. In addition, the remaining 4% unpaid 1st Semester grants will be posted once the payment is released to the HEIs.

PANOORIN: Laging Handa Dokyu 4.0 - Ang Pamana: Ligtas na Balik Eskwela

Isa ang edukasyon sa mga sektor na labis naapektuhan ng pandemya kung saan maraming paaralan ang nagsara at ang mga estudyante ay napilitang umangkop sa makabagong paraan ng pag-aaral.

Nasubok man ang pasensya at determinasyon ng mga guro, mag-aaral, at maging ng kanilang mga magulang, hindi ito naging hadlang para ipagpatuloy ang pagkatuto ng mga kabataan.

Inihahandog ng Presidential Communications Operations Office - Office of the Global Media and Public Affairs, ang dokyu tungkol sa muling pagbubukas ng mga paaralan para sa face-to-face classes at ang pagsisikap ng gobyerno na masigurong ligtas ang pagbabalik-eskwela.

Ito po ang totoong kwento.

TES Update #10
MGA ORAGON KAN BICOLANDIA KAMO NA MAN!
The P30,000 1st semester subsidy of 9,393 continuing grantees is now available in 40 private higher education institutions (HEIs) in the Bicol Region.

Press Conference on the Implementation of Limited Face-to-face Classes Under Alert Levels System for COVID-19 Response, HEI COVID-19 Vaccination Status, and Participation of CHED and HEIs in the National COVID-19 Vaccination Days

Vaccination rate among faculty and tertiary students get a boost ahead of 2022 - CHED

Vaccination rate among higher education institution (HEI) personnel and tertiary students continue to scale up as the country welcomes a new year.

As of December 29, reports from HEIs all over the country show that 87.1% of HEI faculty and employees have been vaccinated. This is a significant increase from the 72% vaccination rate at the start of the aggressive vaccination campaign in October 2021.

This means that out of the 293,058 teaching and non-teaching personnel all over the country, a total of 255,229 HEI personnel have been vaccinated.

Some of the regions which have the most number of vaccinated HEI personnel are CAR with 95.24% or 7,940 out of the total 8,337 personnel; Region 3 with 94.08% or 24,831 out of 26,393; Region 2 with 93.78% or 8,604 out of 9,175 and Region 11 with 92.16% or 11,542 out of 12,524 HEI personnel.

The vaccination rate for students has also increased from 46% to now 59.7% with the aggressive school-based vaccination drive spearheaded by CHED in cooperation with the Department of Health (DOH), the National Task Force (NTF) Against COVID-19, local government units (LGUs), and partner HEIs.

To date, out of the reported number of tertiary students or 4,115,988, a total of 2,456,667 have been vaccinated. From this number, 43.21% are fully vaccinated while 16.42% have at least received their first dose.

Some of the regions which have the most number of vaccinated students are Region 9 with 85.38% or 123,897 out of the total number of 145,113 students in the region; Region 3 with 81.12% or 321,946 out of 396,866 and CAR with 75.65% or 84,436 out of 111,617 students.

"The Commission is happy to report that in many regions of the country, the vaccination rate of our education frontliners have reached herd immunity levels ensuring not only their availability to join face-to-face classes but more importantly, they are helping protect their families and communities from the rapid spread of the COVID-19 virus," De Vera said.

"I also commend all our CHED regional offices, HEIs, their partner LGUs, and DOH personnel for their dedicated partnership during the 3-day Bayanihan, Bakunahan: Ligtas, Lakas, Buong Pilipinas through their school-based vaccination sites and for mobilizing medical and nursing student-volunteers in vaccination sites all over the country," he added.

De Vera said that the efforts of CHED regional offices, HEIs and their partner LGUs will now expand to help education stakeholders get booster shots in the first quarter of 2022 to facilitate the expansion of face to face classes and be part of the national effort to combat any COVID variant that may enter the country.

(SIGNED)
J. PROSPERO E. DE VERA III, DPA
Chairman
Commission on Higher Education

https://ched.gov.ph/vaccination-rate-among-faculty-and-tertiary-students/

Distribution of Tertiary Education Subsidy (TES) Grant to 246 student-grantees under the Unified Financial Assistance System for Tertiary Education Act, or UniFAST -- also known as Republic Act No. 10687. Each student received 30,000 for the semester which intended to cover academic and extra-curricular expenses, including tuition, miscellaneous and other school fees.

NVC is proud to be instrumental in giving Aklanon students the access to free and quality education which lead to realize and uphold its mission and vision of assisting the needs of the community, especially supporting the education of the students. The educational assistance is a big help to our less privilege students to continue and pursue their much needed education. The students and their parents were very grateful and would like to extend its appreciation to CHED - Unified Student Financial Assistance System for Tertiary Education for the grant.

Education Week Cordillera 2022 Kick-Off Ceremony held today, December 12, 2022, at Baguio Central University, Baguio City. This year's celebration revolves around the theme, "United Education Agencies Towards Cordillera Autonomy," which aims to highlight the significant contributions of the educational agencies, particularly the CHED, TESDA, and DepEd, in attaining autonomy for the Cordillera Administrative Region. Series of events spearheaded by the three aforementioned agencies will be conducted until December 14, 2022.

PADYAK SA KALINGA (12/12): To end the PADYAK Visit in Kalinga, a culminating program was held at Naneng Heritage Village and Rice Terraces. Cultural presentations were performed by the youth of Brgy Naneng and grantees from Kalinga State University. During the program, TES grantee Maribel N. Bilwayan (BSBA) and SIKAP Scholar Mr. Jonathan A. Belandres shared their testimonials and attested to the success of the Higher Education in the country. 
In his message, Chairperson J. Prospero “Popoy” E. De Vera III expressed his gratitude to Kalinga State University, headed by Pres. Eduardo Bagtang, and to the whole Province of Kalinga for their warm accommodation and support. He assured the crowd that his passion to champion accessible and relevant education services for every Filipino youth will continue to prosper.

ANNOUNCEMENT!!

To all Tertiary Education Subsidy (TES) Beneficiaries under the College of Agriculture and Natural Resources (CANR), we would like to inform you that your grant for the 2nd Semester of A.Y. 2021-2022 is available. Kindly check the list below if your name is included then you may now claim your grant at the CNSC Main Campus-Cashier Office starting (Tuesday) December 27, 2022, from 8:00 am to 4:30 pm until December 28, 2022 (Wednesday), 8:00 am to 2:00 pm only.

*NOTE: Please visit first SFAU Office 2nd floor of CNSC Main Campus Library, before claiming your grant to verify if you're enrolled, not enrolled, dropped, or unofficially dropped for the 2nd Semester of A.Y. 2021-2022. (NO VERIFICATION SLIP, NO CLAIM)

WHAT to BRING:
1. Bring your own ballpen.
2. Two (2) A4 size photocopies of your school I.D. with three signatures on the side.

DISCLAIMER: OTHER COLLEGES ON THE MAIN CAMPUS AND SATELLITE CAMPUSES WILL HAVE THEIR SEPARATE SCHEDULE FOR RELEASE. PLEASE WAIT FOR FURTHER ANNOUNCEMENTS OF YOUR SCHEDULE. THERE'S A PROCESS TO BE FOLLOWED, REST ASSURED SAME BATCHES FOR TES WILL BE RELEASED. NO NEED TO FOLLOW UP WITH YOUR COLLEGE ABOUT IT.

THANK YOU!

-SFAU Team

Mindoro State University (MinSCAT)

𝗦𝘁𝗮𝘁𝗲𝗺𝗲𝗻𝘁 𝗼𝗳 𝗖𝗛𝗘𝗗 𝗼𝗻 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝘀𝘁𝗮𝘁𝗲𝗺𝗲𝗻𝘁 𝗼𝗳 𝗨𝗣 𝗗𝗶𝗹𝗶𝗺𝗮𝗻 𝗼𝗳𝗳𝗶𝗰𝗶𝗮𝗹𝘀 𝗼𝗻 𝗦𝗨𝗖𝘀 𝘁𝗮𝗸𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗼𝘂𝘁 𝗖𝗧𝗚 𝗺𝗮𝘁𝗲𝗿𝗶𝗮𝗹𝘀 𝗳𝗿𝗼𝗺 𝘁𝗵𝗲𝗶𝗿 𝗹𝗶𝗯𝗿𝗮𝗿𝘆
02 November 2021
The decision to remove books and other reading materials from a university library is done by individual higher education institutions (HEIs) in the exercise of academic freedom. There are reasons why some HEIs have decided to remove materials donated by government-declared Communist-Terrorist Groups (CTGs) in their libraries. School authorities in these HEIs are in the best position to explain why. They are given sufficient administrative discretions under existing laws.
Three state universities - Kalinga State University, Isabela State University, and Aklan State University — recently pulled out reading materials from their libraries and turned these over to the regional National Task Force to End Local Communist Armed Conflict (ELCAC) and/or the National Intelligence Coordinating Agency.
HEIs must respect these decisions of other HEIs in the spirit of mutual respect and  proper governance of their institutions. 
I know that there are many HEIs that are critical of the policies adopted by the University of the Philippines (UP) Diliman officials and the way they run their campus but they are not issuing statements out of mutual respect for the governance of individual public universities. 
I urge UP Diliman officials to  do the same.
It would be best for the Chancellor of UP Diliman and other officials to be more prudent, circumspect, respectful and discerning in issuing statements especially involving the exercise of academic freedom of other higher education institutions.
(SIGNED)
J. PROSPERO E. DE VERA III, DPA
Chairman
Commission on Higher Education

Thankful po ako sa CHED kasi isa po ako sa mapalad na nakatanggap ng TES. Malaking katulungan po ito sa aking pag aaral. Maraming maraming salamat po.

Ask ko lang po, dahil nung 1st year college po ako sa TDP po ako napasali (ndi po kasi ako nakapag apply for TES kasi ndi po pasok ung lugar nmin for subsidy) dahil no choice nman po ako nag apply po ako sa TDP, nakasali po ako at nakatanggap. Pero nung 2nd year po ako nag apply po ako ulit para subsidy at thankful po at nakapasok ako (tumira po ako at sa lugar Ng Lola ko kung saan pasok ung lugar ng Lola ko for subsidy). Nung naglabas na ng list sa TDP nakasama po ulit ako. Kaso ndi ko na po tinanggap ung sa TDP kasi daw ikakaltas daw sa subsidy ko yun. (Eh naglabas po ang school nmin Ng final list for subsidy at nakasama ako). Kakatanggap ko lang po nung Feb 14 Ng subsidy kinaltas ung 15k kasi po tumanggap daw po ako nung 1st year ako sa TDP.

1st year sa TDP lang ako kasali (kasi Po no choice Wala nman po akong mapapagkuhaan na iba).

2nd year napasama sa final list Ng subsidy (nag apply po ulit ako).

Paano po kaya yun? Mababalik kaya po ung 15k ang laki po kasi nung nakaltas eh. Malaking tulong pa Po sana sakin yun para sa pangtustos Ng gamot ni papa at para sa pangangailangan ng pamilya ko.

INSTITUTIONAL VISIT AT APAYAO STATE COLLEGE: Right after his PADYAK Visit in Kalinga, CHED Chairperson Dr. J. Prospero “Popoy” E. De Vera III visited Apayao State College on March 04, 2022. He led the groundbreaking ceremony of the Three-Storey General Education Curriculum Building and the ribbon-cutting of the newly established open gymnasium of ASC – Conner Campus. 
During the institutional visit, three TES grantees of ASC shared their life stories and testimonies regarding the Tertiary Education Subsidy program and the Free Higher Education. Joyce Guzman (BSE Social Studies), Joyce Batugal (BSE English), and Laura Ettong (BSE Social Studies) expressed their gratitude for TES and FHE which was made possible during the present administration.
In his message, Chair Popoy emphasized the importance of education in eradicating intergenerational poverty in the country. 
“Every peso that we put for free higher education is not an expense, it is an investment for the future of our country. The best investment is to invest in our young people, to make them better. Because by making them better, they will make their future families better than their situation. And by doing so, they end poverty at their level. They do not transfer to the next generation the poverty that they experienced. That is the philosophy of free higher education: we give our young people a chance,” he said.
He also noted that although the work as a public servant is tiring, every blood, sweat, and tears poured into service was worth giving whenever he encounters grantees whom their lives changed due to the Free Higher Education and Tertiary Education Subsidy.
Also present during the event was CHED-CAR Director and OIC-Office of the President of ASC, Dr. Demetrio P. Anduyan Jr., Municipal Administrator of Conner, Apayao, Mr. Shariff B. Eboy, SUC President of Kalinga State University, Dr. Eduardo Bagtang, and representatives from CHED-CAR UniFAST Unit led by Ms. Menzie O. Kuengan, OIC-CEPS, and Dr. Bernadette C. Pal-ec, Education Supervisor II and UniFAST Focal Person.

#MyKwentongCHEDUniFAST Digital Content Creation Webinar Series

Just be yourself. Be authentic. For vlogger and social media influencer Mark "Macoy Dubs" Averilla, staying true to yourself is key in creating content that can facilitate human connection. He also added that when content creators share their own own personal experiences, they establish a connection with their audience.

Editor and filmmaker Tara Illenberger reminds all aspiring content creators to know their limitations because by doing so, they will be able to know how to overcome these challenges and enhance their skills more as editors. Try using free mobile apps to edit. Take free courses and online tutorials. Start shooting and creating content with your mobile phone. There are always ways to be resourceful and these will help you hone your editing skills.

Content is king. For award-winning filmmaker Arjanmar Rebeta, even with just a smartphone, the possibilities are endless for content creators as long as they have a story they wish to tell the world.

MEET THE FINALISTS OF THE CINEISKOOL FILM FESTIVAL. From the pool of entries from Luzon, Visayas, and Mindanao, 10 short films have been selected to compete at the CineIskool Film Festival spearheaded by the Film Development Council of the Philippines (FDCP) and the Commission on Higher Education (CHED) with its attached agency, Unified Student Financial Assistance System for Tertiary Education (UniFAST).

The screenings will be held from June 22 to 25 at the Gateway Cineplex in Quezon City. Which among these films are you most excited to see? Let us know in the comments!

CineIskool aims to produce and exhibit films with diverse stories that highlight the significance and benefit of tertiary education to encourage the youth to take advantage of the different education assistance programs by the government. #CineIskoolFilmFestival #TeamFDCP

Please like and follow the page, everyone! Kabataang Iskolar ng Pilipinas, ang Pili ninyo ang kinabukasan ng ating bansa. The Philippine 2022 National Elections is upon us; are you ready to use your vote as your voice? Introducing PILI-PinaSkolar Halalan, your go-to online guide for your smart choice! PILI-PinaSkolar Halalan is a platform aimed to educate the people particularly the higher education/youth sector, which comprises more than half of the voting population of the Philippines, in relation to the upcoming May 2022 Elections. Our mission is to encourage youth to exercise the right to suffrage, expose disinterested information of the aspirants, circulate collaterals on the do's and don'ts weeks before and on the day of the elections, and aid in the decision making of the youth to pick the best choice from the variety of contenders. We envision a country with fair and just government built with strong foundation from the elected officials who are education champions and stresses importance on the provision of education for the youth. #PILIPinaSkolarHALALAN2022 #PLPS2022

"[Ang salitang YABONG] ay binibigkas nang malumanay at walang impit. Nagpapakita lamang na ang proseso ng pagyabong ay hindi minamadali. This is a long continuing process. The process of growth cannot be done overnight. It is a long enduring process to make the flower bloom despite of what the environment is.

Ito ay mahabang proseso; ito ay dahan-dahan [at] hindi minamadali. Kaya nga ang pagpunta ng ating mga estudyante sa Cordillera Administrative Region o mag-enroll sa mga paaralan, ang pagdevelop sa kanila ay isang matiyaga at mahabang proseso hangga't matamo nila ang full development.

And there's no other best place for you to learn, re-learn and blossom as the best flower that you can be except in the Cordillera Administrative Region: the best environment where one will grow, where one would be able to fully realise his or her full potential. Because amidst perplexities and complexities when you are questioning what kind of future you will have, the best place for you to find yourself is in the Cordilleras."

-Dir. Demetrio P. Anduyan Jr, Director IV of CHED-CAR, during the conduct of the 2022 Project YABONG Student Congress on November 09, 2022, at King's College of the Philippines, La Trinidad, Benguet

To all TDP-TES Grantees under the College of Business and Public Administration (Batch 3, Batch 4, Batch 5 and Batch 7) Main Campus we would like to inform you that your grant for the 2nd Semester of A.Y. 2020-2021 is available. What is TES and how to apply in TES?

The Tertiary Education Subsidy or more popularly known as "TES" is a grant-in-aid program that provides financial assistance to support at least the partial cost of tertiary education, inclusive of education-related expenses. It prioritizes students belonging in lower-income households and provide access to quality tertiary education in city/town without state or local universities and colleges.

To find out more, visit: https://www.unifast.gov.ph/tes.php

FEATURE STORY: Did you know that the number of female grantees for the Tulong Dunong Program in the Cordillera Administrative Region is almost thrice as many as the male grantees?

The CHED Tulong Dunong Program aims to provide financial assistance to qualified and deserving students. It is intended for the ongoing grantees and new applicants who are enrolled or will enrol in CHED-recognized programs of Private Higher Education (Private HEIs) or State Universities and Colleges (SUCs)/ Local Universities and Colleges (LUCs) with Certificate of Program Compliance (COPC).

In the Cordillera Administrative Region, the number of female grantees for the Tulong Dunong Program is almost thrice as many as the male grantees. Among the 6,350 grantees for the 2nd Semester of SY 2020-2021, 74.35% are female grantees while only 25.65% are male.

With this number, as we celebrate this year's Women's Month, it is, therefore, safe to say that Philippine higher education is victorious in making change work for women by making quality education affordable and universal to them.

Highlights of the 2022 MIMAROPA Localized Student TES Congress
The Commission on Higher Education UniFAST MIMAROPA conducted a 2022 MIMAROPA Localized Student TES Congress Featuring: #TESayawitngKabataan2022 “Tugtugan, Edukasyon at Sayawan” with the theme: “Itanghal, Husay at Galing ng Kabataang MIMAROPA, Inspirasyon ng susunod na Henerasyon” hosted by John Paul College last November 11, 2022.
The celebration commenced with welcome remarks from the president of John Paul College, Dr. Rosalina Andaya, followed by a TES Congress Message from the CHED Regional Director Atty. Joselito C. Alisuag.
This was followed by Leadership Training with the theme “Redefining Leadership” and Career Guidance Training with the theme “Your Career Development Cycle” by Dr. Mark Anthony Latoja who served as the resource speaker during the training. Thereafter, the Contemporary Dance Contest kicked off the competition declaring John Paul College’s entrants Mr. Samnehvid John C. Bello and Ms. Abby D. Elpedes as grand winners, and the first place was awarded to Prince of Peace College’s entrants Mr. Mhike Methesuel Tadle and Ms. Dianna Espares. Following that, participants were also enlivened as the most awaited performances from the TES Focals for Focal Showdown Season 2 commenced where John Paul College’s TES Focal Mr. Rommel M. Madrona was declared as the grand winner, and first place was awarded to Prince of Peace College Focals Ms. Maria Bisa, Mr. Salvador Tizon, Ms. Dianne Magbuhos, Ms. Andrea Sandoval, and Ms. Cassius Justianano. 
Breath-taking performances were one of the most awaited acts of the celebration when the Battle of the Band begins that makes the crowd go wild making the EMA EMITS College Philippines “Naranja” band the grand winner, while City Colleges of Calapan’s “Banda ni Kali” proclaimed as the first runner up in the competition. On top of that, Mindoro Vice Governor Ejay Falcon delighted the crowd by visiting John Paul College to give his TES Congress inspirational message to the students and participants of the celebration.
Lastly, The CHED UniFAST MIMAROPA, headed by Regional Director Atty. Joselito Alisuag, would like to thank John Paul College for hosting the magnificent and successful localized TES Congress. This event will not be possible without the support and cooperation of the JPC Officials and Staff, also the students and officials from Private Higher Education Institutions (PHEIs) and Local Universities and Colleges (LUCs) from the region who participated and attended the celebration. See you at the Regional TES Congress in Palawan!
Youtube: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5R20eVd4wjI

TES UPDATE #33
Nakapasok na rin ang TES sa MIMAROPA!
Finally, we are excited to announce that the TES grant for the 436 continuing grantees in two (2) private higher institutions of MIMAROPA Region was already disbursed.
Each of the grantees will receive a subsidy of P30,000 for the 1st Semester of Academic Year 2020-2021. As of now, a total of P13,256,250 was paid by UniFAST through the help of CHED Regional Office MIMAROPA.
For the remaining private HEIs of the region, two (2) are already available for disbursement, 19 are currently waiting for the budget from the DBM, and nine (9) will also receive the TES upon completion of the billing requirements. We will post your HEIs as soon as they receive your TES from the CHED Regional Office. Tiwala lang! ☝🏻

Agyaman nak UniFAST TES, dakkel ti tulong u ti panagbasak.

Isa akong anak ng isang Brgy. Tanod at Solo parent, makitaltalon, maki lablaba ti pagsapulan ni mamang ko ken maysa kami beneficiaries ti 4p's. 1st year ako noong nawala ang aking tatay at naging isa akong breadwinner sa aming pamilya. Simula 1st year hanggang 4th year ipinagmamalaki ko na akoy isang iskolar at dahil dito akoy nakapag tapos ng kolehiyo. Dahil sa scholar na ito natulongan ko din ang aking mama sa pag aaral ng aking mga nakakabatang kapatid lalo na noong pandemya.

Sana marami pang estudyante ang mapabilang sa scholar na ito at sana maging responsable sila sa perang makukuha nila at gagamitin sa tamang paraan.

Lubos po akong nagpapasalamat sa lahat ng tulong ng aking scholar na TES, at maraming salamat din sa lahat ng bumubuo ng Unifast, Sir J. Prospero De Vera III, Chairman (Commission on Higher Education) and UniFAST Board. Sa ating Pangulong Rodrigo Roa Duterte maraming salamat po dahil isa akong nakinabang sa iyong legasiya na libreng edukasyon dahil sa Republic Act. 10931(Universal Access to Quality Tertiary Education)
MARAMING SALAMAT PO!

RAMOS, OLIVER DELA ROSA
Ilocos Sur Polytechnic State College,
University of Ilocos Philippines (UIP)

Bachelor of Science in Agriculture Major in AGRONOMY
